p: H9N2 is frequently isolated from, and therefore probably endemic in poultry in many Middle Eastern countries including Egypt, Iran, Israel, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates [ 14, 20, 34, 38, 42, 43, 44]. The virus has also been isolated regularly in Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon and Oman [ 39, 45, 46, 47, 48]. In Israel, mass vaccination of poultry, which began in 2003, has had some success in limiting the endemicity of the virus. This vaccine regime has necessitated an update of the vaccine seed strain at least once due to antigenic drift [ 49]. Extensive surveillance in Israel, between 2006 and 2012, has indicated that rather than there being a single locally evolving strain, viruses appear to be periodically eradicated, then reintroduced into the country.
